utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And why are you carrying a vial of it around with you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman was perfectly healthy before he got this infection. Our cop wasn’t, he had Legionnaire’s Disease. Our cop didn’t turn into brain food until we cured the legionella. Legionella slowed down the disease.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why would that happen?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No idea. Just know that it did.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So you want to infect Foreman?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You gonna tattle to the CDC?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The meds can’t help me but a disease can? Forget it, just take the pain away and put me under!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I put you under I can’t monitor your pain. If I can’t monitor your pain I can’t tell if the legionella’s working.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m not consenting to you giving me – What was that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmmm, wish there could have been a puff of smoke or something. Would have been much more dramatic. Keep your slippers on, wouldn’t want you to cut your foot.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are you feeling any better?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I can’t breathe, I’m dizzy, and I can barely hear anything over the sounds of my lungs crackling.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s the legionella.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh. You figure that out from the symptoms or from the vial House tossed into my room?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m trying to be professional here. There’s no reason to be nasty.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m in pain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So is House.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And he’s a delight!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He doesn’t try to kill his colleagues. You can remove the thermometer now. It’s down almost a whole degree! How’s the pain?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Great. It’s the good kind.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How bad is it compared to an hour ago?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No worse.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The legionella helping?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But not great. It didn’t fix anything, it just slowed it down. The whole point was to give Steve a little more time to get sick.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What are you going to do if he never gets sick?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Brilliant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cameron, what kind of illnesses affect humans but not rats?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why are you asking me that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I’m sure you spent the first twelve years of your life dreaming of being a vet. The rat is not getting sick. Cameron is not getting sick.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s okay. It’s not your fault. Presumably you’re still healthy because whatever it is is not blood borne. Steve has no excuse; he did everything that Foreman did.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Some bacterial infections don’t affect rats.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Foreman tested negative for every bacterial infection that would affect his brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And what infections could he be positive for but test negative for? When we test for infections, we look for antibodies. Now, what if the patient is infected, but has no antibodies – what if the body is not fighting the infection?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why would –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neh, eh, I asked first. Let’s start with the ‘what’, we’ll deal with the ‘why’ later.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If the body doesn’t recognize the infection our tests come back negative and the disease rampages through the body unstopped.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly like the cop and exactly like Foreman. And what if the patient was then exposed to a second infection, like legionella? The body would recognize that infection, increase the white count, send in the troops to start fighting, and the initial infection would get caught in the crossfire. So the question becomes, what type of bacterial infection affects humans and not rats, and the human body would be unlikely to recognize.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The answer is listeria. I’m starting you on amp and gent.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you’re basing this theory on the tests being negative and your rat being healthy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the fact that Legionnaire’s is helping you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But the medicine you wanna give me will put an end to that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And if it’s not listeria all the gent will do is cure the Legionnaire’s Disease and put whatever is killing me back into overdrive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop asking me questions based on the premise that I’m wrong. The antibiotics are in the airlock.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think the first biopsy didn’t give us the answer because you didn’t go deep enough. I want you to do a white matter brain biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely. Don’t blame you. The world is such a complicated place if you’ve got higher reasoning skills. I’m often jealous of smaller animals and retarded children. Take the antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There can be minimal damage if it’s done right. If the surgeons drill where I tell them to drill.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One slip, you could spend the rest of your life not being able to keep your drool in your mouth.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’d rather be disabled than dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, I make it look oh-so-sexy. It’s actually not as glamorous as you may think.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The biopsy will tell us for sure what’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The antibiotics could do the same thing!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could! Not will.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We try it, we see!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The antibiotics will bring back the pain!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pain makes us make bad decisions. Fear of pain is almost as big a motivator. Now look, we still have time. I will do that biopsy if I have to, but not a moment before.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start Foreman on IV antibiotics. Where’s his dad?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where are you supposed to be when your son is dying?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s not with him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s in the chapel.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve started your son on a new course of treatment. If it works, he’ll get better. If it doesn’t, he won’t. While he’s not getting better, he’s going to experience so much pain that we’ll have to put him in a chemically-induced coma while we figure out what to do next.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: My son says you’re a manipulative bastard.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s a pet name. I call him Dr. Bling.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: I assume you’re here for a reason. What do you want from me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When your son is in a coma you’re the one who’s going to have to make the medical decisions for him.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Oh, whatever you decide is fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t care what I do?

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: I’m not a doctor, what do I know? Except what Eric tells me. He says you’re the best doctor he’s ever worked with.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I need your help.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s nothing I can give you for the pain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I wanna be put out.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can have a nurse in here in five minutes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, once I’m out I might not come back. I’ve never done a will.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’ll call a lawyer for you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I want you to be my medical proxy. All the things that piss me off about you in House’s office: too emotional, too caring, too cautious… they’re all good things on this floor.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Your dad is –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He cares about you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So do you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can’t do this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We expect family members to make decisions about their loved ones after a ten minute briefing that we’re agonizing over even with years of medical experience.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s from my article.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m sorry, Allison. I shouldn’t have stolen your article, I shouldn’t have exposed you. You are a friend, I need to know that we’re okay.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. I’ll be your proxy, but we’re not okay. You’re scared, you’re dying, but that’s the only reason you wanna set things right. We’re gonna get you better first, and then, if you still want to apologize, I’ll be around. I’ll call that lawyer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any improvements?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. As far as we can tell the only improvements the antibiotics are treating is the legionella. I think we need to consider alternate theories.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Like what?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We do the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give the antibiotics more time.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There is no more time; the pain was almost unbearable already!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So he’s almost in unbearable pain, he’s not almost dead, which means we have more time.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mr. Foreman? We need to put your son in a coma. You should be there.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: It’s a medical procedure, right?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, but once we put him out, if we don’t solve this, he won’t wake up.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: What should I say? Should I talk to him like it’s going to be okay? Or should I be saying goodbye? I need to know what people say when –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Just tell him you love him.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Hey, son.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, Dad.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: It’s going to be okay.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don’t know that.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don’t.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: I don’t wanna miss you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I love you too, Dad. Hey, it’s gonna be okay. Can we do this now?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, of course. I accept your apology.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why weren’t you with Foreman?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hang out in the basement, you rag on me. I stay in my office, you rag on me. Honky just can’t buy a break.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Based on the cop’s progression I figure he’s got another four hours before –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You figure? You’re playing Russian Roulette but the gun’s pointed at him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Cutting open his head is what’s dangerous.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, it’s dangerous. Well, what would people think? The reason you don’t see patients is because if you know them, you’ll give a crap about them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know you –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you give a crap about them, you stop making outrageous calls. If this was any other patient you’d have damned the risks and cut their head open a long time ago.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s out. The EEG shows he’s still in pain, the antibiotics have had more than enough time, we’re doing the brain biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not unless you people can’t come up with something clever in the next three hours.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Now, we’re doing it now!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, who died and made you boss?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s legal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s out of his mind! Yesterday he was giggling about a hole in a guy’s head.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then hire a laywer and challenge it. In the mean time, Cameron’s in charge.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Why would he sign that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s nothing personal, Mr. Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: My son doesn’t trust me – how exactly is that not personal?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re sorry? You’re talking about this man’s son. You’re denying him the right to be a part of –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, shut up, House. If you want to do the biopsy, do the biopsy. If House tries to interfere, let me know and I will take care of it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, you’re a hero. If it wasn’t for you, we’d be cutting into a dead guy’s head instead of Foreman’s. Sorry. Thanks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That was great!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It was rude and unnecessary.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give me time.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re out of time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: An hour.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What does “out of time” mean?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His O2 stats are at 94 right now. As long as they’re above 90 the danger of fatal arrhythmia doesn’t increase.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So what? There’s no point in waiting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You were right. We should be cutting into a corpse’s head.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah! We should be, except the CDC has got the cop’s body under –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s got to be other bodies.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You think this thing has killed other people?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, that apartment was a dump. Just because Steve McQueen didn’t get sick doesn’t mean some other varmint didn’t. You give me an hour, I go back there and find a dead animal, we cut its head open instead of Foreman’s.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Foreman’s already at 100% oxygen. Once his O2 stats hit 90, I can’t wait any longer. Where’s your suit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either you’ll find the answer, or I’ll find the answer. Doesn’t matter.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Prep the drill. We’ve gotta be ready if we get the signal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Found a blind bird.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Great. How fast can you get it in here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll know in about 30 seconds.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You better have the bird, the surgical team’s in place.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How can you not capture a blind bird?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not what I meant. I screwed up the first time through this place.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Foreman told you everywhere he went.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not where, it’s when. He came here in the early afternoon. Me and Steve came two hours too late, you came six hours too early. It’s the water, the irrigation system only pumps –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, I tested the water, the water’s clean! House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We tested the wrong water. He stole cable, he stole fertilizer, and he stole water. It’s riddled with Naegleria.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You already did the biopsy?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I thought I had no choice.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: How’s my son?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He has primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. It’s a parasite that goes through the nose and migrates into the brain, where it feeds on brain cells. The legionella attacked the parasite, that’s why the disease slowed down.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Is it treatable?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We started him on an antiparasitic and the amoebas will clear out of his system.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: And then he’ll be okay?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And then we’ll wean him out of the coma –

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Will he be okay?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’ll be no lasting damage from the parasite.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: But the surgery?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We don’t know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Up and at ‘em.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How’re you feeling? Can you talk?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t feel anything.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Are you numb?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, I mean, I don’t feel any pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Keep your head still and follow my finger.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your breath stinks, you’re peeing into a bag. What are our names?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You did the biopsy? Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Names.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cameron, my dad, and the manipulative bastard.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You remembered.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’re you doing, Dad?

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: Great, relieved… great.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What did I have?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Naegleria. Biopsy showed the amoeba, CDC autopsy eventually found the amoeba, and House found it in the water in the cop’s roof.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wiggle your left toes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wait, you went back and she did the biopsy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your left toes, Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I just did.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Rodney
utterance.content: He can’t move his toes?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He can move them. Raise your right arm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What?
